xyz.acygn.mokapot

Class TCPCommunicationAddress

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.acygn.mokapot.TCPCommunicationAddress
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CommunicationAddress, Copiable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    LoopbackCommunicationAddress, SiteLocalCommunicationAddress, StaticInternetCommunicationAddress

    public abstract class TCPCommunicationAddress
extends Object
implements CommunicationAddress
    An implementation of a communication address that assumes that each system involved in the distributed communication has an IP address via which all other machines can contact them on a specified port. Because this assumption is not true in general, even for machines that are networked together or Internet-connected, this class is abstract, and subclasses are defined for certain special cases where the assumption works correctly:
    • LoopbackCommunicationAddress - Handles the situation where the distributed communication runs entirely on a single physical machine.
    • SiteLocalCommunicationAddress - Handles the situation where all the machines involved in the distributed are connected together via a site-local network.
    • StaticInternetCommunicationAddress - Handles the situation where all the machines involved are connected to the Internet, and have a static, externally visible IP address (i.e. inbound connections will be routed to the machine, rather than being interrupted by a firewall or NAT).
    Author:
    Alex Smith
    See Also:
    LoopbackCommunicationAddress, SiteLocalCommunicationAddress, StaticInternetCommunicationAddress

    • Constructor Detail

      • TCPCommunicationAddress

        protected TCPCommunicationAddress()
        Protected constructor. Handles any initialisation required for all TCPCommunicationAddress objects. At present, there is no initialisation code common to all such objects, so this constructor has no effect.

    • Method Detail

      • fromInetAddress

        public static TCPCommunicationAddress fromInetAddress(InetAddress address,
                                                      int port)
        Creates a TCPCommunicationAddress of an appropriate subclass, for communicating with a machine at the given IP address and port. Note that this assumes that all machines involved in the computation will understand the given IP address as written; for example, if the address is a loopback address, then only one machine can be involved in the computation (as other machines would give a different interpretation to the loopback address, treating it as referring to a different machine). If the IP address to use for a connection varies from one machine to another, you cannot use this factory method, and will need to subclass TCPCommunicationAddress yourself.
        Parameters:
        address - The IP address via which communication is made to the machine you wish the return value to represent.
        port - The port via which communication is made to the VM you wish the return value to represent.
        Returns:
        A communication address that represents TCP communication via a constant IP address and port.

      • asInetAddress

        public abstract InetAddress asInetAddress()
        Returns an Internet address via which the machine at this communication address can be contacted. Unlike a CommunicationAddress, where a machine must always be referred to by a constant address no matter which machine is doing the referring, the return value of this method may depend on the machine on which it is called. (Or to think of it another way: within a particular distributed cluster, there's a unique, 1-to-1 relationship between a virtual machine and its communication address, but asInetAddress returns information for this VM to contact the VM at the other end of the connection, which does not necessarily have to work for other connections.)

        If this method does not return a locally deterministic value (i.e. the same value every time it is called from a single specific machine), you must override Object#equals() and Object#hashCode() in order to ensure that your communication addresses compare correctly.

        Returns:
        An Internet address that can be used to contact the machine at this communication address.

      • getTransmissionPort

        public abstract int getTransmissionPort()
        Returns the port number to use when sending a message to the virtual machine at this address. As with asInetAddress(), this can in theory depend on the machine on which the method is called (although in practice, this is unlikely).

        If this method does not return a locally deterministic value (i.e. the same value every time it is called from a single specific machine), you must override Object#equals() and Object#hashCode() in order to ensure that your communication addresses compare correctly.

        Returns:
        A TCP port number that can be used together with the return value of asInetAddress() to contact the virtual machine at this communication address over TCP.
        See Also:
        asInetAddress()

      • newListenSocket

        public ServerSocket newListenSocket()
                             throws IOException
        Creates a new TCP-based ServerSocket that listens for incoming communication. Should only be called if this address refers to the local machine; the socket will be created in such a way that other machines can contact this machine using information in a copy of this communication address.
        Specified by:
        newListenSocket in interface CommunicationAddress
        Returns:
        A ServerSocket bound to the TCP port specified by this address, initially bound but not listening.
        Throws:
        IOException - If something goes wrong trying to create the socket

      • newSendSocket

        public Socket newSendSocket()
                     throws IOException
        Creates a new TCP-based ServerSocket that can send outgoing communication to this address.
        Specified by:
        newSendSocket in interface CommunicationAddress
        Returns:
        An open, connected Socket bound to the IP address and TCP port specified in this communication address.
        Throws:
        IOException - If connections cannot be established

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object obj)
        Compares the IP address and port of this address to the given address. Note that you will have to override this method if the method used to determine IP addresses or ports is nondeterministic, and may want to do so if the method used to determine IP addresses or ports is slow.

        Note that because only one communication address should be used for any given virtual machine in any given distributed computation, and communication addresses are copied field-by-field, this is basically just a field-by-field comparison on all the fields we're aware of (class, address, and port).

        Specified by:
        equals in interface CommunicationAddress
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        obj - The address to compare to. If this isn't the same class as this address has, returns false.
        Returns:
        True if the addresses represent the same virtual machine; false otherwise (or if the other address isn't a TCPCommunicationAddress object).
        See Also:
        Object.hashCode()

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns a consistent number for any given communication address. This aims to produce distinct numbers for distinct communication addresses, but this cannot always be guaranteed.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        A number such that a.equals(b) implies a.hashCode() == b.hashCode()

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Produces a string representation of this communication address.
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        The stringification of the IP address, a colon, and the TCP port in use.
